head.title: Catalytic Synergy on PtNi Bimetal Catalysts Driven by Interfacial Intermediate Structures | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Catalytic Synergy on PtNi Bimetal Catalysts Driven by Interfacial Intermediate Structures

Platinum-based bimetallic catalysts exhibit surface atomic rearrangement in various adsorbate environments, which significantly impacts catalysis. A molecular-level understanding of intermediate structures created during catalysis is essential for developing high-performance bimetal catalysts. We show that intermediate Pt–NiO1–x interfacial structures drive the catalytic synergistic effect observed on Pt3Ni nanocrystals. Real-time microscopic observations at ambient pressure show the formation of oxygen-driven Ni oxide clusters on the surface and provide direct evidence of Pt–NiO1–x interfacial structure formation. Spectroscopic analysis, including ambient-pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy, and catalytic measurements elucidate the role of Pt–NiO1–x interfacial structures and the catalytic reaction mechanism in CO oxidation. Our results indicate that metal-oxide interfacial intermediate structures in bimetal catalysts relate to the catalytic enhancement of the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect.

div.span: Supporting Info (2)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Platinum-based bimetallic catalysts exhibit surface atomic rearrangement in various adsorbate environments, which significantly impacts catalysis. A molecular-level understanding of intermediate structures created during catalysis is essential for developing high-performance bimetal catalysts. We show that intermediate Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structures drive the catalytic synergistic effect observed on Pt
3
Ni nanocrystals. Real-time microscopic observations at ambient pressure show the formation of oxygen-driven Ni oxide clusters on the surface and provide direct evidence of Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure formation. Spectroscopic analysis, including ambient-pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy, and catalytic measurements elucidate the role of Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structures and the catalytic reaction mechanism in CO oxidation. Our results indicate that metal-oxide interfacial intermediate structures in bimetal catalysts relate to the catalytic enhancement of the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Pt-3d transition-metal (TM) bimetallic catalysts (e.g., Pt–Ni, Co, Fe, and Cu) have attracted significant research attention for catalytic reactions at solid/liquid or solid/gas interfaces.
(1−4)
The Pt-3d TM bimetallic system shows enhanced catalytic activity, attributed to its modified electronic structure. According to the d-band electronic model, the molecular interaction between adsorbates and the metal surface is related to the d-band center shift. This electronic modification facilitates significantly easier adsorption and/or desorption of adsorbates on the surface of the Pt-3d TM bimetallic catalyst.
(5−7)

Designing an efficient heterogeneous catalyst requires an understanding of the restructuring kinetics of Pt-3d TM bimetallic catalyst surfaces. The surface restructuring both affects the change of electronic structure and serves as a unique strategy for enhancing catalytic activity under the oxidation catalytic reaction. The bimetallic synergistic approach is mainly introduced in the bimetal catalyst, which improves the catalytic performance by changing the atomic restructuring during the catalytic reaction.
(8−12)
This concept is relevant to the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect, which occurs when a noble metal (e.g., Pt and Au) coexists with a reducible metal oxide (e.g., TiO
2
, CeO
2
, Co
3
O
4
, and NiO).
(13−16)

Pt-3d TM bimetallic catalysts often show the formation of intermediate metal-oxide interfaces during the reaction and similar catalytic behavior with SMSI in terms of the interaction between Pt and reducible oxides driven by the atomic restructuring. Because the formation of intermediate metal-oxide interfaces in the bimetal catalysts is essentially similar to that in metals on oxide supports, we propose that the concept of the SMSI effect can be used to explain the catalytic properties in bimetal catalysts. Earlier density-functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated the surface restructuring of the Pt-3d TM bimetallic system; the results showed that the 3d TM in the bimetallic system prefers the subsurface (Pt/TM/Pt structure) under reductive conditions and the topmost surface (TM/Pt/Pt structure) under oxidizing conditions.
(17,18)
Surface restructuring has also been experimentally reported in a Pt-3d TM bimetallic system. Lee et al. experimentally elucidated surface restructuring in a Pt
3
Ni(111) model system under an oxygen environment, resulting in the formation of oxygen-induced Ni oxide species on a Pt
3
Ni(111) surface.
(19)
With the results of the model system, Xin et al. also confirmed the surface restructuring in Pt–Co nanocrystal systems under oxygen conditions and showed the formation of epitaxial CoO films on the nanoparticle (NP) surface.
(20)
The oxygen-induced 3d metal oxides, formed on the adjacent noble metal in bimetallic catalysts, revealed bimetallic synergy. However, technical limitations make it challenging to investigate catalysis under the reaction environment, and much remains unresolved.

Recently, the development of state-of-the-art micro/spectroscopic technology has enabled
in situ
/
operando
characterization at surface-sensitive levels in the catalytic environment.
(21−26)
It is possible to observe real-time imaging under various gas conditions using aberration-corrected environmental transmission electron microscopy (E-TEM). Lee at al. observed the formation of the Pt–CoO interface in PtCo bimetallic NPs using E-TEM under oxygen conditions; the interfacial structure facilitated the efficient transport of electrons and showed higher catalytic activity during the hydrogen oxidation reaction.
(27)
Ambient-pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-XPS) and diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) measurements enable real-time analysis related to the molecular interaction between adsorbates and the catalyst surface during solid/gas catalytic reactions. Wu et al. uncovered bimetallic synergy at the CoO
x
/Pd interface in Co–Pd nanocatalysts using AP-XPS under a CO oxidation environment.
(8)
Thus, these
in situ
/
operando
surface characterizations strengthen the case for designing advanced industrial catalysts by bridging the pressure gap of catalysis. Previously, Kim et al. reported the formation of Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structures and their role in the CO oxidation reaction in a Pt
3
Ni(111) model system using
operando
AP scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and AP-XPS, which related to bimetallic synergy.
(28,29)
Bridging the material gap in the industry requires an understanding of surface chemistry in single crystals as well as nanoparticle bimetal surfaces during the catalytic conditions.
(30)

In this study, we report the direct observation, using the
operando
spectroscopic investigation, of the structural change in a Pt
3
Ni nanocrystal system during CO oxidation and its role in the catalytic condition. To uncover the molecular dynamics of catalysis for CO oxidation in the nanocrystal system, we prepared the stoichiometric Pt–Ni bimetallic NPs
via
the conventional polyol method. From the
ex situ
energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping and XPS investigation, we confirm that the surface restructuring of Ni atoms takes place in the Pt
3
Ni nanocrystal and then forms Ni oxide species on the nanocrystal surface. Through the combined real-time imaging by E-TEM and
operando
spectroscopic techniques by near AP-XPS (NAP-XPS) and DRIFT, the formation of Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structures in a Pt
3
Ni nanocrystal system has been confirmed and the role of Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structures in bimetallic synergy determined.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 2.1. Synthesis of Pt–Ni, Pt, and Ni NPs

div.div:
We adopted the conventional polyol method for synthesizing the Pt
3
Ni bimetallic NPs.
(31)
In a typical synthesis of Pt
3
Ni NPs, 200 mg of platinum(II) acetylacetonate [Pt(acac)
2
, 97%, Sigma-Aldrich], 13 mg of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate [Ni(ac)
2
·4H
2
O, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich], and 10 mg of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP,
M
w
= 10 000, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 5 mL of ethylene glycol (Sigma-Aldrich) in a 50 mL three-neck round-bottom flask. The solution was heated to 353 K and then the flask was evacuated for 20 min. The evacuated flask was purged with Ar gas for 10 min. The solution was heated to 503 K and kept at this temperature for 10 min with vigorous stirring. The transparent solution turned black during the heating at 453 K, indicating the formation of colloidal Pt
3
Ni NPs. After the reaction, the solution was cooled down to room temperature (RT). The colloidal suspension of Pt
3
Ni NPs was diluted to 50 mL by acetone and centrifuged at 6500 rpm for 10 min. The as-synthesized NPs were redispersed in ethanol. For the PtNi
3
bimetallic NPs, the elemental ratio of nickel acetate to platinum acetylacetonate was adjusted to 1:3 with the amount of the platinum precursor fixed.

In a typical synthesis of Pt NPs, 20 mg of ammonium tetrachloroplatinate(II) [(NH
4
)
2
PtCl
4
, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich], 120 mg of tetramethylammonium bromide [(CH
3
)
4
N
+
(Br
–
), 98%, Sigma-Aldrich], and 100 mg of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP,
M
w
= 29 000, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 10 mL of ethylene glycol (Sigma-Aldrich) in a 50 mL three-neck round-bottom flask. The mixed solution was heated to 353 K, and then the flask was evacuated for 20 min. The evacuated flask was purged with Ar gas for 10 min. The solution was heated to 453 K, and it was kept at this temperature for 20 min with vigorous stirring. After the reaction, the solution was cooled down to RT. The colloidal suspension was diluted to 50 mL by acetone and centrifuged at 6500 rpm for 10 min. The as-synthesized Pt NPs were redispersed in ethanol.

For the synthesis of Ni NPs, 10 mg of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate [Ni(ac)
2
·4H
2
O, 98%, Sigma-Aldrich] and 50 mg of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP,
M
w
= 10 000, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 15 mL of ethylene glycol (Sigma-Aldrich) in a 50 mL three-neck round-bottom flask. The mixed solution was heated to 353 K, and then the flask was evacuated for 20 min. The evacuated flask was purged with Ar gas for 10 min. The solution was heated to 453 K, and it was kept at this temperature for 20 min with vigorous stirring. The solution was heated to 393 K, and then 50 mg of sodium tetrahydroborate (NaBH
4
, 98%, JUNSEI) was added. The solution was kept at this temperature for 1 h with vigorous stirring. After the reaction, the solution was cooled down to RT. The colloidal suspension was diluted to 50 mL by acetone and centrifuged at 6500 rpm for 10 min. The as-synthesized Ni NPs were redispersed in ethanol.

We examined the chemical composition of Pt–Ni (Pt
3
Ni and PtNi
3
) NPs using inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS; 7700S ICP-MS, Agilent) and X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF; ZSX Primus II, Rigaku). For the crystallinity examination of Pt–Ni NPs, X-ray diffraction (XRD; Ultima IV, Rigaku) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) was carried out for all samples. The images of Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and the Pt monolayer film on a SiO
2
substrate were obtained using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM; Magellan400, FEI Company).
Ex situ
chemical binding analysis was performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; K-Alpha, Thermo VG Scientific).

div.h3:
2.3.
Ex Situ
and
In Situ
TEM Measurement
div.div:
Transmission electron microscopy, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM, HAADF-STEM, and EDS; Titan cubed G2 60–300, FEI) were operated at 200 kV to
ex situ
investigate the morphology and chemical composition change of Pt
3
Ni NP. An aberration-corrected environmental transmission electron microscope (Titan E-TEM G2, FEI) operating at 300 kV with a Fusion heating holder (Protochips Inc.) was used for the
in situ
TEM observations. For the E-TEM investigation, the Pt
3
Ni NPs were supported on spherical SiO
2
particles with a diameter of 400 nm. The Pt
3
Ni/SiO
2
sample was dropped on the Fusion heating holder, and then the Pt
3
Ni/SiO
2
sample was heated from RT to 423 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C min
–1
in 7.5 mTorr of O
2
gas for 50 min inside the transmission electron microscope.

The
Operando
DRIFT technique was performed using a Fourier-transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR; Carry 660, Agilent) equipped with diffuse reflectance optics (Harrick), a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector (every 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm
–1
), and ZnSe windows integrated into the reaction cell. The inside of the spectrometer was purged by purified helium (He) gas during all measurements. The DRIFTS cell was connected to a heater and gas lines that were controlled by mass flow controllers (Brooks Instrument).

The Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Pt NPs were supported on the commercial SiO
2
NPs (SiO
2
, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) with a size of 10–20 nm for DRIFT investigations. Pt
3
Ni and Pt/SiO
2
powders (1 wt %) were mechanically pressed onto a prepared stainless steel mesh to prevent potential exposure to contamination in the reactor cell. To examine the vibrational frequency shifts of adsorbate molecules on the Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Pt/SiO
2
catalysts during CO oxidation, the samples were exposed to 100 mL min
–1
CO/O
2
/He gas mixture flow (CO + O
2
feed, 1:2.5 v/v, CO oxidation environment) conditions before the DRIFT measurements at an elevated temperature.

div.h3:
2.5.
Operando
NAP-XPS and Catalytic CO Conversion Measurements
div.div:
Chemical binding species on the Pt–Ni nanocrystal surface were analyzed using the NAP-XPS technique of the Advanced
in situ
Surface Analysis System (AiSAS) at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI) in the Republic of Korea. The custom-built NAP-XPS setup consists of an
operando
high-pressure reaction cell, a microfocused X-ray source (Al Kα,
E
= 1486.74 eV), and a PHOIBOS 150 NAP hemispherical electron analyzer (SPECS). As-prepared Pt
3
Ni nanocrystals on the Si substrates were rapidly transferred to the reaction cell without vacuum loss. For
operando
NAP-XPS analysis, the CO (5 N) gas was purified with brass wool heated at 523 K, and O
2
(5 N) gas was used without further purification. The amounts of the gaseous reactant and product inside the reaction cell during CO oxidation were monitored using a residual gas analyzer (MKS instruments e-Vision 2) at the third pumping stage in the system. Core-level spectra in the regions of Pt 4f and Ni 2p were recorded with an energy step of 0.05 eV and a pass energy of 50 eV, of which binding energy was calibrated with respect to the Fermi edge. Detailed instrumental information of AiSAS is described elsewhere.
(32)

div.h3: 2.6. Measurement of Catalytic Activity for CO Oxidation
div.div:
For fabrication of samples for the catalytic reaction, the Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Pt NPs were assembled to a two-dimensional monolayer on a SiO
2
substrate using a Langmuir–Blodgett trough (LB; M611, KSV NIMA). The catalytic reaction was carried out in an ultrahigh vacuum chamber (1 L) with a base pressure of 10
–8
Torr evacuated using rotary and turbomolecular pumps. A batch reaction chamber isolated by a gate valve was filled with 40 Torr CO and 100 Torr O
2
as the reactant gases and 620 Torr He as the balancing gas. All of the gases were mixed and circulated continuously through the reaction line using a Metal Bellows recirculation pump (MB-41) at 2 L min
–1
. After 20 min of circulation for equilibration of the mixed gases, a gas chromatograph (GC; DS6200 gas chromatograph, Donam Instrument Inc.) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a 6 ft long, 1/8 inch outer diameter stainless steel molecular sieve 5A was used to separate the reactants (CO and O
2
) and products (CO
2
) for analysis. CO conversion into CO
2
was measured, depending on the reaction temperatures (433–513 K). The measured reaction rates were reported as the turnover frequency (TOF). The Pt active area was determined by geometrical considerations because there is not much difference between real surface area and apparent surface area in Pt thin films.
(33)

All of the TOF data were obtained by measuring the CO oxidation rate at low conversion (
i.e
., conversion less than 20%), presuming that the initial reaction rate was in a kinetically controlled regime.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Uniform-sized Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Pt NPs were successfully prepared, each about 6 nm (
Figure
1
a–c). The lattice fringe of Pt
3
Ni NPs with an interfringe distance of 0.193 nm was consistent with the typical (200) plane of reference Pt (platinum; JCPDS #04-0802) in a face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure (the inset of
Figure
1
a). Also, the interfringe distances of PtNi
3
and Pt NPs were 0.224 and 0.226 nm, respectively, which correspond to the typical (111) plane of reference Pt (insets of
Figure
1
b,c). For detailed characterization of the Pt–Ni bimetallic NPs, additional microstructures of Pt, Pt
3
Ni, and PtNi
3
NPs were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (
Figure S1
). The diffraction patterns of Pt, Pt
3
Ni, and PtNi
3
NPs exhibited typical (111) and (200) diffraction peaks of the crystalline reference Pt in an fcc lattice structure without impurities (for example, metallic Ni, NiO, and PtO). Hence, both Pt
3
Ni and PtNi
3
NPs were successfully synthesized to Pt–Ni bimetals. In particular, the peak shift of diffraction patterns from the reference Pt to a higher angle as the content of Ni increased means that the lattice constant decreases as Pt is replaced with Ni in the crystal lattice.
(34)
With the Pt–Ni bimetallic and Pt NPs, about 6 nm Ni NPs were also prepared, as shown in
Figure S2a,b
. The Ni NPs were also successfully synthesized without impurities, as shown in
Figure S2c
.

div.p:
Figure 1. Characterization and reaction data of CO oxidation of as-synthesized Pt–Ni nanoparticles. Representative TEM and corresponding HRTEM images in insets of as-synthesized (a) Pt
3
Ni, (b) PtNi
3
, and (c) Pt nanoparticles. (d) Catalytic activity for CO oxidation of Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Pt catalysts on a SiO
2
substrate obtained by a batch reactor under 40 Torr CO, 100 Torr O
2
, and 620 Torr He mixed gas (reactant gas: CO + O
2
; 1:2.5 ratio, balancing gas: He). (e) Comparison of TOF as a function of the fraction of Ni at 473 K.

div.div:
Along with the structural analysis, the chemical composition of the Pt–Ni bimetallic NPs is investigated in
Figure S3
. In the case of Pt
3
Ni NPs, according to X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF), inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS), and EDS mapping analysis, the compositions of the Pt-to-Ni atomic ratio are 73.86 to 26.14, 72.7 to 27.3, and 72.34 to 27.66, respectively. On average, the atomic ratio of Pt to Ni is about 3 to 1 in Pt
3
Ni NPs. In the other case of PtNi
3
NPs, according to XRF, ICP-MS, and EDS analysis, the compositions of the Pt-to-Ni atomic ratio are 32.78 to 67.22, 22.85 to 77.15, and 22.54 to 77.46, respectively. The atomic ratio of Pt to Ni is about 1 to 3 in PtNi
3
NPs. Therefore, the Pt–Ni nanocrystals were successfully prepared for the study of surface phenomena during catalysis.

div.h3:
3.2. Catalytic Activity and Structural Changes of Pt
3
Ni Nanocrystals
div.div:
As a model system for studying bimetallic synergy by surface restructuring, the CO oxidation reaction was chosen due to the representative and straightforward solid–gas heterogeneous catalytic reaction. For the investigation of catalytic performance by a batch reactor, the Pt, Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Ni NPs were assembled into a two-dimensional monolayer on a SiO
2
substrate using the Langmuir–Blodgett trough technique (
Figure S4
). The catalytic activities of Pt–Ni and Pt catalysts are shown in
Figure
1
d,e. The Pt
3
Ni NPs show greater catalytic activity than PtNi
3
and Pt catalysts during the CO oxidation. However, the Pt catalyst shows lower catalytic performance than Pt–Ni NPs. Also, the Ni catalyst shows little catalytic activity (
Figure S5
). The trend of catalytic activity with a different fraction of Ni is displayed at 473 K in
Figure
1
e. The Pt–Ni bimetallic catalysts have a higher TOF value than the monometallic Pt catalyst. These catalytic trends are also observed from the activation energy barrier plot with different ratios of Pt–Ni composition in
Figure S6
. The Pt
3
Ni catalyst shows the lowest catalytic activation energy barrier. Further investigation of the surface chemistry for Pt
3
Ni nanocrystals should be pursued to look into the superior catalytic property of Pt
3
Ni catalysts for CO oxidation.

Surface restructuring, induced by temperature and adsorbates, should be understood in the bimetallic system, because it may affect the enhancement or suppression of the chemical reaction. The schematic illustration shows the formation process of an oxygen-driven Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure in Pt
3
Ni nanocrystals in
Figure
2
a. The surface restructuring in the Pt–Ni bimetallic system has been introduced in previous model studies.
(19,28,29)
To examine the distinct change of chemical composition in Pt
3
Ni NPs,
ex situ
XPS and scanning TEM (STEM)-EDS mapping analysis were performed to confirm the kinetics of nickel oxide formation, as shown in
Figure
2
b–f. First, the
ex situ
Ni 2p core-level XP spectrum of Pt
3
Ni NPs was recorded after oxidation pretreatment at 298, 373, and 523 K (
Figure
2
b). For Ni 2p spectra analysis, it is possible to make a qualitative analysis of metallic Ni, NiO, Ni
2
O
3
, and satellites by comparing the XP spectra at different pretreated temperatures.
(19,28,29,35)
The Ni
2
O
3
signal comes from the surface defect structure of NiO (
i.e
., metastable NiO).
(36)
In this study, we classify the Ni oxidation states into two types, metallic Ni and nickel oxide complexes (NiO, Ni
2
O
3
, and satellites). As the temperature increases, the formation of Ni
2
O
3
occurs first, followed by satellite and NiO formation. The
ex situ
STEM-EDS mapping analysis was carried out, as shown in
Figure
2
c–f. Before the pretreatment process, Pt atoms are mainly distributed in the surface region (
Figure
2
c,d). After pretreatment at 523 K in oxygen conditions, Ni restructuring takes place toward the surface (
Figure
2
e,f). The
ex situ
XPS and STEM-EDS mapping analysis indicate that the oxygen-driven Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure formed on the surface of Pt
3
Ni NP. The results can also be supported by
ex situ
high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) investigation, as shown in
Figure S7
. After the pretreatment at 523 K in oxygen conditions, the inter-fringe distance of 0.240 nm at the topmost surface corresponds to the typical (111) plane of reference NiO (nickel oxide; JCPDS #47-1049) in a face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure. This oxidative trend can be more easily confirmed in PtNi
3
NPs, as shown in
Figure S8
. The
Figure S8
clearly shows that nickel oxide complexes formed on the PtNi
3
surface. Compared to Pt
3
Ni, a thicker NiO cluster formed on PtNi
3
. We can confirm island forms of NiO, as shown in the region of the yellow dotted line. From the
ex situ
HRTEM investigations of Pt
3
Ni and PtNi
3
, the island forms of nickel oxide complexes were mainly formed on the nanoparticles by the reaction with O
2
molecules, which do not completely cover the NP surface.

div.p:
Figure 2. Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure formation of a Pt
3
Ni nanoparticle after O
2
annealing. (a) Schematic illustration of the formation process of an oxygen-driven Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure of a Pt
3
Ni nanocrystal. (b)
Ex situ
Ni 2p core-level XP spectra at different annealing temperatures (298, 373, and 523 K). Representative (c) STEM and (d) elemental mapping images of Pt
3
Ni nanoparticles before annealing. Representative (e) STEM and (f) elemental mapping images after annealing at 523 K in O
2
conditions. Elemental mapping: Pt and Ni.

div.h3:
3.3.
Operando
Studies of Pt
3
Ni Nanocrystals
div.div:
Aberration-corrected E-TEM analysis was performed to figure out the formation kinetics of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure. The real-time interaction between the exposed surface of Pt
3
Ni NPs and adsorbates (O
2
molecules) at 395 K is introduced in
Movie S1
. For explaining the oxygen-driven Ni restructuring on the Pt
3
Ni surface, time-sequenced E-TEM images of the Pt
3
Ni NPs at the initial state and at 30 and 57 s during the oxidation reaction are displayed in
Figure
3
. As the reaction progressed, we confirmed the distinct morphological changes. At the initial reaction, a Pt
3
Ni NP shows clear hexagonal-shaped morphology, including {111} and {200} facets, marked with a yellow dotted line in
Figure
3
a. As the reaction progresses, hexagonal-shaped morphology breaks and the phase separation occurs at the exposed surface. It follows a similar tendency of the previously reported
in situ
E-TEM study for CuO
x
species formation on Cu metal in an O
2
environment.
(37,38)
The CuO
x
species were confirmed by a poor crystalline or amorphous phase in the TEM image. Likewise, the distinguishable phase (pointed out by white arrows in
Figure
3
b) might be considered in the formation of Ni oxide complexes with poor crystallinity. At 57 s after the reaction in
Figure
3
c, the morphology of the Pt
3
Ni NP turned into the spherical shape (marked with the blue dotted line). Also, the crystal structure of inside NPs was also maintained with the fcc structure during the reaction (marked with the yellow dotted line), which is also confirmed by comparing the fast Fourier-transform (FFT) patterns in the left images of
Figure
3
d,e. We can observe the conclusive change on the surface of Pt
3
Ni NPs during the oxidation reaction by comparing the right images of
Figure
3
d,e. An ambiguous surface of the initial Pt
3
Ni NPs was clearly transformed into the nickel oxide complexes on Pt–Ni NPs. These results are consistent with
ex situ
STEM-EDS mapping and Ni 2p core-level XPS analysis (
Figure
2
), directly indicating the oxygen-driven Ni restructuring on the Pt–Ni NPs.

div.p:
Figure 3.
In situ
formation of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure on the Pt
3
Ni nanoparticle surface. Time-sequenced E-TEM image of the Pt
3
Ni NP under 7.5 mTorr of O
2
gas at 395 K: (a) initial state and after (b) 30 and (c) 57 s. Corresponding fast Fourier-transform (FFT) patterns (left) and enlarged E-TEM image (right) at (d) initial state and (e) after 57 s. All scale bars are 2 nm.

div.div:
For unraveling the role of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure during the catalytic reaction, mass spectrometry combined with
operando
NAP-XPS measurements for Ni 2
p
core level was performed in CO oxidation conditions under CO and O
2
mixed gas (1:2.5 ratio), as shown in
Figure
4
. The mass spectrometry profiles of reactants and products with temperature and time are shown in
Figure
4
a, which facilitates the monitoring of real-time catalytic behavior at the five-step elevated temperatures (298, 380, 425, 470, and 515 K). There was no apparent catalytic reaction until 425 K. When the temperature reached 470 K, dramatically enhanced CO
2
evolution occurred as the number of reactants (CO and O
2
) decreased. As the temperature reached 515 K, CO
2
evolution increased vertically with increasing temperature. Surprisingly, catalytic activity changes at the moment the temperature reaches 470 and 515 K are quite different. In the former case (at 470 K), it is observed that CO
2
evolution gradually increased compared with the latter case (at 515 K). It can be explained by the investigation of chemically bonded species in Pt
3
Ni NPs during CO oxidation.

div.p:
Figure 4. Mass spectrometry profiles and
operando
NAP-XPS measurements of Pt
3
Ni nanoparticles under 300 mTorr CO and 750 mTorr O
2
mixed gas (1:2.5 ratio) at elevated temperatures. (a) Time-lapse mass fragment profiles for
m
/
z
= 32 (O
2
; green solid line),
m
/
z
= 28 (CO; blue solid line), and
m
/
z
= 44 (CO
2
; red solid line), and temperature profiles at 298, 380, 425, 470, and 515 K. (b) Ni 2
p
3/2
core-level NAP-XP spectra (Al Kα; 1486.7 eV) at less than 470 (<470; 298, 380, and 425), 470, and 515 K. The spectra at <470 K is the average intensity of 298, 380, and 425 K under a mixed gas. (c) Surface Pt and Ni ratio of Pt
3
Ni nanoparticles in ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) at 298 K and under mixed gas conditions at 298, 380, 425, 470, and 515 K from the spectra of
operando
NAP-XPS. The spectra were processed by subtracting the Shirley background.

div.div:
The oxidation state in the
operando
Ni 2p core level at each temperature is revealed in
Figure
4
b. The weak intensity of Ni chemical species (metallic Ni and nickel oxide complexes) was observed at less than 470 K (average intensity of 298, 380, and 425 K). The distinguishable intensity of the Ni chemical species began to appear from 470 K, and it was saturated at 515 K. There are two reasons for the poor intensity of Ni chemical species under 425 K. One is the presence of a carbonaceous capping layer confirmed in
Figure S9
. As carbonaceous materials were removed by an oxidation reaction, the intensity of the Pt 4f spectrum increased. The other reason comes from the low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the NAP-XPS. The NAP-XPS is optimized to obtain the spectrum by capturing core-level electrons in the ambient environment, which is slightly lower in resolution than conventional XPS for ultrahigh vacuum (UHV). Although it is difficult to check the chemical states of Ni 2p because of the poor SNR in the low-temperature region, we can confirm the restructuring phenomenon by comparing the surface ratio of Ni and Pt (
Figure
4
c). The portion of surface Ni chemical species increased as the temperature increased, which indicates that Ni restructuring mainly takes place from 470 K. Clearly, the nickel oxide complexes are actively formed from 470 K, which agrees with the results of
ex situ
(XPS and STEM-EDS mapping) and
in situ
(E-TEM) investigations. The formed nickel oxide complexes remained after the CO oxidation reaction, as shown in
Figure S10
. Furthermore, the increase in CO
2
evolution at 470 K in
Figure
4
a coincides with the point at which the formation of nickel oxide complexes actively takes place in
Figure
4
b. This indicates that the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure accelerates the catalytic reaction for CO oxidation, which may be attributed to the lowering of the activation energy barrier at the rate-determining step.

To obtain further insights into catalytic molecular behavior during CO oxidation, an
operando
DRIFT measurement was performed, as shown in
Figure
5
. To carry out DRIFT measurements, Pt, Pt
3
Ni, PtNi
3
, and Ni NPs were supported on SiO
2
particles (
Figure S11
). Contour maps show the visualization of the adsorbed CO molecules (linear
v
(C≡O)) on the active site (Pt) with the evolution of CO
2
gas molecules (
v
as
(C═O) band) for Pt
3
Ni and Pt catalysts in
Figure
5
a,b, respectively. Also, plots of the linear
v
(C≡O) position with the intensity of the
v
as
(C═O) band for Pt
3
Ni and Pt catalysts are represented in
Figure
5
c,d, respectively. Detailed spectra of Pt
3
Ni and Pt catalysts are displayed in
Figure S12a,b
, respectively. DRIFT results of Pt
3
Ni and Pt catalysts show three distinct differences: first, the Pt
3
Ni catalyst exhibits the active conversion of linearly adsorbed CO molecules into CO
2
gas from 460 K, whereas CO conversion in the Pt catalyst takes place actively from 517 K. As mentioned in the NAP-XPS results, this is regarded as an improvement in catalytic activity by bimetallic synergy at the Pt–Ni
1–
x
interfacial structure. For this reason, the PtNi
3
catalyst also shows relatively better catalytic performance than that of the Pt catalyst (
Figure S13a,b
). However, the PtNi
3
catalyst exhibits a lower catalytic activity than that of the Pt
3
Ni catalyst, because it has fewer active sites (Pt sites) and a low proportion of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure. Second, the peak position of linear
v
(C≡O) in the Pt
3
Ni catalyst (2081 cm
–1
) is shifted to a higher wavenumber than in the Pt catalyst (2057 cm
–1
), which indicates that the electronic structure of Pt atoms, alloying with Ni atoms, changes due to the d-band center shift.
(5−7)
The changed electronic structure by the d-band center shift makes a weaker bond with CO molecules than the Pt catalyst. After the CO oxidation, we also confirmed the shifted peak position of linear
v
(C≡O) in the Pt
3
Ni catalyst at 2091 cm
–1
, as shown in
Figure S14
. On the other hand, the peak position of linear
v
(C≡O) was not found in the spectrum of the NiO
x
catalyst (O
2
-pretreated Ni NPs for 1 h at 500 K), as shown in
Figure S15
. This indicates that the nickel oxide complexes cannot act as an active site for the CO oxidation reaction. From the DRIFT spectra of NiO
x
and Pt
3
Ni (after CO oxidation) catalysts, we conclude that the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure is formed and NiO
x
does not fully cover the Pt
3
Ni NP surface. Third, the catalytic mechanism for the CO oxidation of Pt sites is quite different between Pt
3
Ni and Pt catalysts. The formation of surface oxides in the Pt catalyst has previously been reported under CO oxidation reactions.
(39−41)
Hence, the Pt catalyst shows the distinctive blue shift below the ignition temperature at around 500 K (
Figure
5
b,d), indicating the formation of surface oxides on the Pt catalyst. However, the Pt
3
Ni catalyst shows the constant peak position at 2081 cm
–1
without a blue shift, which means that the oxidation state of Pt atoms is not changed during CO oxidation. It is also rationalized from the result of Pt 4f in NAP-XPS analysis in
Figure S9
.

div.p:
Figure 5. Catalytic molecular behavior during the CO oxidation reaction at elevated temperatures by
operando
DRIFT measurements. Contour maps of the
operando
DRIFT spectra during the reaction of (a) Pt
3
Ni and (b) Pt catalysts on the SiO
2
support. Plots of the linear
v
(C≡O) peak position (CO
(ads)
) with the intensity of the
v
as
(C═O) band (CO
2
gas) for (c) Pt
3
Ni and (d) Pt catalysts. All DRIFT measurements were performed under a 100 mL min
–1
CO/O
2
/He gas mixture flow (CO + O
2
feed, 1:2.5 ratio) at the elevated temperature.

div.div:
In the previous study, the bimetallic synergy for CO oxidation in the Pt
3
Ni(111) model system was reported by Kim et al.
(28)
The research shows that the CO molecule prefers to adsorb with Pt rather than NiO at the interfacial structure on Pt
3
Ni, and the adsorbed intermediate CO* reacts with the neighboring oxygen species (O*) from NiO
1–
x
to create a COO* intermediate. Then, the COO* intermediate is desorbed to form CO
2
gas molecules. The DFT-calculated activation energy barrier of this mechanism at the rate-determining step is lower than that on Pt(111)
via
the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism. Thus, this mechanism is a thermodynamically efficient reaction pathway in the presence of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure, suggesting that the Pt
3
Ni nanocrystal system also follows a Mars van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism like the Pt
3
Ni(111) model system. The NAP-XPS and DRIFT results confirm the reaction mechanism with the presence of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure. Overall, our result elucidates the essential role of Pt–NiO interfacial structures in the catalytic reaction mechanism for CO oxidation and expands the fundamental understanding of heterogeneous catalysis with potential applications in the rational design of bimetallic catalysts with enhanced catalytic activity.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We show that metal–metal-oxide interfacial nanostructures form under chemical reaction environments at ambient pressure, increasing the catalytic activity of the CO oxidation reaction. Out of four tested PtNi bimetal catalysts, we show that the Pt
3
Ni catalyst showed the best catalytic performance for CO oxidation because of the optimized bimetallic synergy effect at the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure. In Pt
3
Ni nanocrystals, the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure formed by surface restructuring during CO oxidation was clearly uncovered by combined E-TEM and
operando
NAP-XPS techniques. Furthermore,
operando
NAP-XPS and DRIFT measurements elucidated the role of the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interfacial structure in bimetallic synergy, showing that CO molecules are selectively adsorbed on the Pt atoms at the Pt–NiO
1–
x
interface. The effective molecular conversion takes place simultaneously. These results provide conclusive evidence about the role of oxide–metal interfacial sites, which is directly correlated with the SMSI effect using microscopic and spectroscopic
in situ
techniques.

Octahedral PtNi Nanoparticle Catalysts: Exceptional Oxygen Reduction Activity by Tuning the Alloy Particle Surface Composition
Cui, Chunhua; Gan, Lin; Li, Hui-Hui; Yu, Shu-Hong; Heggen, Marc; Strasser, Peter

We demonstrate how shape selectivity and optimized surface compn. result in exceptional oxygen redn. activity of octahedral PtNi nanoparticles (NPs). The alloy octahedra were obtained by utilizing a facile, completely surfactant-free solvothermal synthesis. We show that the choice of precursor ligands controls the shape, while the reaction time tunes the surface Pt:Ni compn. The 9.5 nm sized PtNi octahedra reached a 10-fold surface area-specific (∼3.14 mA/cmPt2) as well as an unprecedented 10-fold Pt mass based (∼1.45 A/mgPt) activity gain over the state-of-art Pt electrocatalyst, approaching the theor. predicted limits.

Du, Xin Xin; He, Yang; Wang, Xiao Xia; Wang, Jian Nong

Catalytic activity and durability improvements are still the main challenges in fuel cell commercialization. To enhance nanocatalyst performance and durability for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), we prep. 3.6 nm sized PtFe particles with a fully ordered intermetallic structure and entrap them in a porous carbon (
[email protected]
). This nanocatalyst toward ORR exhibits 8-10 times enhancement in specific and mass activities over the com. catalyst of Pt/C. Such a large enhancement is the highest, when compared with all other kinds of intermetallic catalysts reported in the literature. Accelerated durability testing has induced only a small change to the ordered structure and a minor loss of the activity after thousands of potential cycles under harsh electrochem. conditions. The high activity and durability are attributed to the fine-grained and ordered structure of the nanoparticle and the confining effect provided by the porous carbon. The nanoparticle,
[email protected]
, represents a new strategy for performance optimization and cost redn. and promoting practical applications of fuel cells.

One-Pot Synthesis of Highly Anisotropic Five-Fold-Twinned PtCu Nanoframes Used as a Bifunctional Electrocatalyst for Oxygen Reduction and Methanol Oxidation
Zhang, Zhicheng; Luo, Zhimin; Chen, Bo; Wei, Chao; Zhao, Jian; Chen, Junze; Zhang, Xiao; Lai, Zhuangchai; Fan, Zhanxi; Tan, Chaoliang; Zhao, Meiting; Lu, Qipeng; Li, Bing; Zong, Yun; Yan, Chengcheng; Wang, Guoxiong; Xu, Zhichuan J.; Zhang, Hua

Unique five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes are synthesized with nanothorns protruding from their edges, based on one-pot hydrothermal method. The time-dependent expt. showed that the pure Cu nanodecahedra were first formed. Then the galvanic replacement reaction between Cu nanodecahedra and Pt precursors in the soln., and the subsequent site-specific co-deposition of Pt and Cu atoms are responsible for the formation of highly anisotropic five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes. Impressively, the as-synthesized five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes exhibit enhanced electrocatalytic activity toward the oxygen redn. reaction and methanol oxidn. reaction as compared to the com. Pt/C catalyst and other reported PtCu nanostructures under alk. conditions. It is believed that the strategy presented here for the rational design and synthesis of five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes might offer a new approach to the construction of other multiply-twinned noble metal alloy nanoframes with various promising applications.

Surface reactivity increases with lattice expansion, following a concurrent up-shift of the metal d states. Consequences for the catalytic activity of thin metal overlayers are discussed.

The application of d. functional theory to calc. adsorption properties, reaction pathways, and activation energies for surface chem. reactions is reviewed. Particular emphasis is placed on developing concepts that can be used to understand and predict variations in reactivity from one transition metal to the next or the effects of alloying, surface structure, and adsorbate-adsorbate interactions on the reactivity. Bimetallic and multi-component catalysts typically exhibit compn.-dependent activity and selectivity, and when optimized often outperform single-component catalysts. Here we used ambient-pressure XPS (AP-XPS) and in situ and ex situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to elucidate the origin of compn. dependence obsd. in the catalytic activities of monodisperse CoPd bimetallic nanocatalysts for CO oxidn. We found that the catalysis process induced a reconstruction of the catalysts, leaving CoOx on the nanoparticle surface. The synergy between Pd and CoOx coexisting on the surface promotes the catalytic activity of the bimetallic catalysts. This synergistic effect can be optimized by tuning the Co/Pd ratios in the nanoparticle synthesis, and it reaches a max. at compns. near Co0.24Pd0.76, which achieves complete CO conversion at the lowest temp. Our combined AP-XPS and TEM studies provide direct observation of the surface evolution of the bimetallic nanoparticles under catalytic conditions and show how this evolution correlates with catalytic properties.

By a combination of catalytic studies and high-resoln. In fact, the in situ partial oxidn. of the ZnPd nanoparticles leads to a large interface between intermetallic ZnPd and small ZnO patches, thus improving the ability of the material to activate water, which results in the high CO2 selectivity. The question of whether a spillover at the formed interface is responsible for the high performance of the catalyst, or if the key reaction steps take place with an increased rate at the interface itself, still remains open.

In2O3 has recently emerged as a promising catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2. In this work, we present the promotional effect of Pd on this catalyst and investigate structure-performance relationships using in situ X-ray spectroscopy, ex situ characterization, and microkinetic modeling. Catalysts were synthesized with varying In:Pd ratios (1:0, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 0:1) and tested for methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 at 40 bar and 300 °C. In:Pd(2:1)/SiO2 shows the highest activity (5.1 μmol MeOH/gInPds) and selectivity toward methanol (61%). While all bimetallic catalysts had enhanced catalytic performance, characterization reveals methanol synthesis was maximized when the catalyst contained both In-Pd intermetallic compds. and an indium oxide phase. Exptl. results and d. functional theory suggest the active phase arises from a synergy between the indium oxide phase and a bimetallic In-Pd particle with a surface enrichment of indium. We show that the promotion obsd. in the In-Pd system is extendable to non precious metal contg. binary systems, in particular In-Ni, which displayed similar compn.-activity trends to the In-Pd system. Both palladium and nickel were found to form bimetallic catalysts with enhanced methanol activity and selectivity relative to that of indium oxide.

The selective oxidn. of ethanol with mol. O2 is increasingly becoming an important process to develop fine chems. because it can be obtained from renewable biomass feedstock while reducing the demand on fossil fuels. We have synthesized silica-supported Au-Cu alloy nanoparticles, and through an oxidative dealloying process, we have developed Au-CuOx hybrid catalysts for the selective oxidn. of ethanol into acetaldehyde. Using a combination of XRD, XPS, and HR-STEM expts., we have confirmed that the active catalyst is a Au core with a thin CuOx shell. Oxidn. of the AuCu/SiO2 alloy catalyst at 300 °C was found to produce the most active and stable catalyst for ethanol conversion (∼90%) with the highest selectivity (∼80-90%) at a reaction temp. of 200 °C for 50 h onstream. TEM and XRD results show that Au-CuOx/SiO2 catalysts calcined at 300 and 500 °C are also more resistant to sintering during pretreatment and catalytic conditions than pure gold supported on silica. Furthermore, the silica-supported Au-CuOx catalysts (calcined at 300 and 500 °C) were also found to be more active and selective in the dehydrogenation of ethanol to form acetaldehyde. It is likely that the increased interfacial contact between the Au and CuOx forms the most active site on the catalyst and is responsible for the enhanced catalytic properties when compared with pure Au/SiO2.

The redn. of noble metals supported on TiO2 at low temps. (200°) produces well-dispersed metals which exhibit the capacity to sorb both hydrogen and carbon monoxide. Redn. of the same materials at 500°, however, decreases hydrogen and carbon monoxide sorption to near zero in all cases. Electron microscopy and x-ray diffraction show that the loss of this sorption capacity is not due to metal agglomeration. This effect for well-dispersed metals is evidence for a chem. interaction between the noble metal and the support. This work describes a mol.-level investigation of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) in Pt/TiO2 catalysts using sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy. This is the first time that SFG has been used to probe the highly selective oxide-metal interface during catalytic reaction, and the results demonstrate that charge transfer from TiO2 on a Pt/TiO2 catalyst controls the product distribution of furfuraldehyde hydrogenation by an acid-base mechanism. Pt nanoparticles supported on TiO2 and SiO2 are used as catalysts for furfuraldehyde hydrogenation. As synthesized, the Pt nanoparticles are encapsulated in a layer of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP). The presence of PVP prevents interaction of the Pt nanoparticles with their support, so identical turnover rates and reaction selectivity is obsd. regardless of the supporting oxide. However, removal of the PVP with UV light results in a 50-fold enhancement in the formation of furfuryl alc. by Pt supported on TiO2, while no change is obsd. for the kinetics of Pt supported on SiO2. SFG vibrational spectroscopy reveals that a furfuryl-oxy intermediate forms on TiO2 as a result of a charge transfer interaction. This furfuryl-oxy intermediate is a highly active and selective precursor to furfuryl alc., and spectral anal. shows that the Pt/TiO2 interface is required primarily for H spillover. D. functional calcns. predict that O-vacancies on the TiO2 surface activate the formation of the furfuryl-oxy intermediate via an electron transfer to furfuraldehyde, drawing a strong analogy between SMSI and acid-base catalysis.

The stability of the Pt-3d-Pt(111) (3d = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, or Ni) bimetallic surface structures in the presence of adsorbed oxygen has been investigated by means of d. functional theory (DFT). The dissociative binding energies of oxygen on Pt-3d-Pt(111) (i.e., subsurface 3d monolayer) and 3d-Pt-Pt(111) (i.e., surface 3d monolayer) were calcd. All of the Pt-3d-Pt(111) surfaces were found to have weaker oxygen binding energies than pure Pt(111) whereas all of the 3d-Pt-Pt(111) surfaces were found to have stronger oxygen binding energies than pure Pt(111). The total heat of reaction was calcd. for the segregation for 3d metal atoms from Pt-3d-Pt(111) to 3d-Pt-Pt(111) when exposed to a half monolayer of oxygen. All of the Pt-3d-Pt(111) subsurface structures were predicted to be thermodynamically unstable with adsorbed oxygen. In addn., the segregation of subsurface Ni and Co to the surfaces of Pt-Ni-Pt(111) and Pt-Co-Pt(111) was investigated exptl. using Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) and high-resoln. electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). AES and HREELS confirmed the trend predicted by DFT modeling and showed that both the Pt-Ni-Pt(111) and Pt-Co-Pt(111) surface structures were unstable in the presence of adsorbed oxygen. The activation barrier of the segregation of subsurface Ni and Co atoms was detd. to be 15 ± 2 and 7 ± 1 kcal/mol, resp. These results are further discussed for their implication in the design and selection of cathode bimetallic electrocatalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in polymer electrode membrane (PEM) fuel cells.

The challenge of chem. in the 21st century is to achieve 100% selectivity of the desired product mol. in multipath reactions ("green chem.") and develop renewable energy based processes. Surface chem. and catalysis play key roles in this enterprise. Development of in situ surface techniques such as high-pressure scanning tunneling microscopy, sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy, time-resolved Fourier transform IR methods, and ambient pressure XPS enabled the rapid advancement of three fields: nanocatalysts, biointerfaces, and renewable energy conversion chem. In materials nanoscience, synthetic methods have been developed to produce monodisperse metal and oxide nanoparticles (NPs) in the 0.8-10 nm range with controlled shape, oxidn. states, and compn.; these NPs can be used as selective catalysts since chem. selectivity appears to be dependent on all of these exptl. parameters. New spectroscopic and microscopic techniques have been developed that operate under reaction conditions and reveal the dynamic change of mol. structure of catalysts and adsorbed mols. as the reactions proceed with changes in reaction intermediates, catalyst compn., and oxidn. states. SFG vibrational spectroscopy detects amino acids, peptides, and proteins adsorbed at hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces and monitors the change of surface structure and interactions with coadsorbed water. Exothermic reactions and photons generate hot electrons in metal NPs that may be utilized in chem. energy conversion. The photosplitting of water and carbon dioxide, an important research direction in renewable energy conversion, is discussed.

Concepts, instruments, and model systems that enabled the rapid evolution of surface science

A review. Over the past forty years, surface science has evolved to become both an at. scale and a mol. scale science. Gerhard Ertl's group has made major contributions in the field of mol. scale surface science, focusing on vacuum studies of adsorption chem. on single crystal surfaces. In this review, we outline 3 important aspects which have led to recent advances in surface chem.: the development of new concepts, in situ instruments for mol. scale surface studies at buried interfaces (solid-gas and solid-liq.), and new model nanoparticle surface systems, in addn. to single crystals. Combined mol. beam surface scattering and LEED- surface structure studies on metal single crystal surfaces revealed concepts, including adsorbate-induced surface restructuring and the unique activity of defects, at. steps, and kinks on metal surfaces. We have combined high pressure catalytic reaction studies with ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) surface characterization techniques using a UHV chamber equipped with a high pressure reaction cell. New instruments, such as high pressure sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) which permit mol.-level surface studies were developed. Tools that access broad ranges of pressures can be used for both the in situ characterization of solid-gas and solid-liq. buried interfaces and the study of catalytic reaction intermediates. The model systems for the study of mol. surface chem. have evolved from single crystals to nanoparticles in the 1-10 nm size range, which are currently the preferred media in catalytic reaction studies.

The structure of the Cu-Co (CuCo) surface alloy, formed by Co deposition on Cu(110), in dynamic equil. with CO, was studied. Using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), in vacuum at room temp. and at low Co coverage, clusters of a few Co atoms substituting Cu atoms form at the surface. At CO pressures in the Torr range, ≤2.5 CO mols. can bind on a single Co atom, in carbonyl-like configurations. Based on high-resoln. STM images, together with d. functional theory calcns., the most stable CuCo cluster structures formed with bound CO were detd. Such carbonyl-like formation manifests in shifts in the binding energy of the Co core-level peaks in x-ray photoelectron spectra, as well as shifts in the vibrational modes of adsorbed CO in IR reflection absorption spectra. The multiple CO adsorption on a Co site weakens the Co-CO bond and thus reduces the C-O bond scission probability. The results may explain the different product distribution, including higher selectivity toward alc. formation, when bimetallic CuCo catalysts are used compared to pure Co.

The catalytic performance of nanoparticles is primarily detd. by the precise nature of the surface and near-surface at. configurations, which can be tailored by post-synthesis annealing effectively and straightforwardly. Understanding the complete dynamic response of surface structure and chem. to thermal treatments at the at. scale is imperative for the rational design of catalyst nanoparticles. Here, by tracking the same individual Pt3Co nanoparticles during in situ annealing in a scanning transmission electron microscope, we directly discern five distinct stages of surface elemental rearrangements in Pt3Co nanoparticles at the at. scale: initial random (alloy) elemental distribution; surface platinum-skin-layer formation; nucleation of structurally ordered domains; ordered framework development and, finally, initiation of amorphization. Furthermore, a comprehensive interplay among phase evolution, surface faceting and elemental inter-diffusion is revealed, and supported by atomistic simulations. This work may pave the way towards designing catalysts through post-synthesis annealing for optimized catalytic performance.

Surface segregation-the enrichment of one element at the surface, relative to the bulk-is ubiquitous to multi-component materials. Using the example of a Cu-Au solid soln., we demonstrate that compositional variations induced by surface segregation are accompanied by misfit strain and the formation of dislocations in the subsurface region via a surface diffusion and trapping process. The resulting chem. ordered surface regions acts as an effective barrier that inhibits subsequent dislocation annihilation at free surfaces. Using dynamic, at.-scale resoln. electron microscopy observations and theory modeling, we show that the dislocations are highly active, and we delineate the specific at.-scale mechanisms assocd. with their nucleation, glide, climb, and annihilation at elevated temps. These observations provide mechanistic detail of how dislocations nucleate and migrate at heterointerfaces in dissimilar-material systems.

Despite numerous studies, the origin of the enhanced catalytic performance of bimetallic nanoparticles (NPs) remains elusive because of the ever-changing surface structures, compositions, and oxidation states of NPs under reaction conditions. Abstr.: Quant. measurement of the no. of active surface sites on two-dimensional (2D) catalysts is one of the most crucial points in heterogeneous catalysis because it is used to det. the turnover frequency (TOF), which refers to the catalytic activity of model catalysts. However, because of the difficulty in identifying the effective active surface area on 2D heterogeneous catalysts, there is still the assumption that each metal atom is an active site. To shed light on these issues and to bridge the activity gaps between 2D and three-dimensional (3D) heterogeneous catalysts, we present an exptl. approach that uses Pt nanoparticle (NP) arrays on a thin silicon wafer probed with CO pulse chemisorption, a widely used surface-sensitive technique, to det. the no. of active sites and the area of the effective active surface. A Pt thin film and Pt NP arrays with two different NP sizes (i.e., 2.1 and 4.5 nm) were prepd. as model systems for 2D catalysts. The effective active metal surface area detd. using CO pulse chemisorption for these 2D catalysts is 53-79% of the apparent metal surface area that was obtained by measuring the surface area based on SEM images. This discrepancy between the active and apparent surface area is attributed to the presence of hydrocarbon contamination and org. capping layers on the catalysts. The results indicate that estg. the active sites of 2D catalysts by apparent surface area is reasonably in agreement with the no. measured by chemisorption that is used to characterize 3D nanocatalysts. This exptl. technique on 2D catalysts can be expected to provide information for extg. the true TOF of product mols. on 2D catalysts in gas-phase catalytic reactions.

For small values of x (x < 0.6) no substantial changes in the lattice size are obsd. upon dissoln. of Fe or Ni suggesting that the dissolved transition metals originate from the surface. However, for electrocatalysts with x > 0.6, the lattice const. expands indicating that transition metals dissolve also from the bulk. XPS results show complete removal of surface Ni (Fe) after acid treatment at 80 °C for all compns. The results of the acid treatments compare well to the compn. changes that occur when a Pt1-xFex or Pt1-xNix combinatorial catalyst library is used in an operating PEM fuel cell.

Molecular adsorption on oxide surfaces: electronic structure and orientation of nitric oxide on nickel oxide(100)/nickel(100) and on nickel oxide(100) as determined from electron spectroscopies and ab initio cluster calculations
Kuhlenbeck, H.; Odoerfer, G.; Jaeger, R.; Illing, G.; Menges, M.; Mull, T.; Freund, H. J.; Poehlchen, M.; Staemmler, V.; et al.
Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics

; ISSN:

.
The adsorption of NO was studied on a thin NiO(100) film of several layers thickness grown on top of a Ni(100) surface in comparison with data of an in vacuo cleaved NiO(100) single crystal. The layer exhibits a high defect d. XPS, angle-resolved RUPS near-edge x-ray-absorption fine structure (NEXAFS), and high-resoln. EELS studies indicate that this layer has similar occupied (ARUPS) and unoccupied (NEXAFS) states as a bulk NiO(100) sample. In spite of its limited thickness, the band structure of the film exhibits dispersions perpendicular to the surface compatible with bulk NiO(100). It is shown that the electronic structure of the O sublattice can be described in a band-structure picture, while for the Ni sublattice, electron localization effects lead to a breakdown of the band-structure picture. The NO on NiO desorbs at 220 K. This indicates weak chemisorption. The NO coverage is ∼0.2 relative to the no. of Ni surface atoms as detd. by XPS. HREELS reveals that there is only one species on the surface documented by th observation of only one bond-stretching frequency. NEXAFS data on the system and a comparison with previous data on the system NO/Ni(100) indicate that the mol. axis of adsorbed NO is tilted by an angle ∼45° relative to the surface normal. The N 1s XPS spectra of the weakly chemisorbed species show giant satellites similar to the previously obsd. cases for weak chemisorption on metal surfaces. This is the first observation of an intense satellite structure for an adsorbate on an insulator surface, which shows that there must be sufficient screening channels even on an insulating surface. A theor. assignment of the peaks is discussed. Spectroscopic properties of the NO species on the thin-film oxide surface (which is likely to contain a certain no. of defects) are compared with those of NO adsorbed on a basically defect-free bulk oxide surface by thermal-desorption (TDS) and XP spectra. TDS and XP spectra of the bulk system are basically identical as compared with the oxide film, indicating that the majority of species adsorbed on the film is not adsorbed on defects but rather on regular NiO sites. Results of ab initio oxide cluster calcns. are used to explain the bonding geometry of NO on regular NiO sites.

The surface chem. of the Ni-O system was studied by using both temp. changes and ion bombardment as techniques for elucidating the surface structure. The spectra of metallic Ni, NiO and Ni2O3 were characterized from samples prepd. directly in the spectrometer. The Ni2O3 species could be distinguished from an authentic Ni(OH)2 sample from both the x-ray photoelectron lines and the Auger transitions. The oxides of NiO and Ni2O3 could be prepd. by bombardment with low energy (400 eV) O2+ ions as well as by exposure of Ni to O at reduced pressure (∼100 torr). The Ni2O3 was present on most Ni-O surfaces except those prepd. by exposing Ni to air for many hours at high temp. (>600°), indicating that the stability of Ni2O3 decreased as the temp. increased. Exposure of both NiO and Ni2O3 to 400 eV Ar+ ion bombardment caused redn. to metallic Ni. This observation was noted for several other oxides and a prediction of whether or not redn. should be obsd. is presented by examg. the free energy of formation of the mol.

Using in situ at.-resoln. electron microscopy observations, we report observations of the oxide growth during the oxidn. of stepped Cu surfaces. Oxidn. occurs via direct growth of Cu2O on flat terraces with Cu adatoms detaching from steps and diffusing across the terraces. This process involves neither reconstructive oxygen adsorption nor oxygen subsurface incorporation and is rather different from the mechanism of solid-solid transformation of bulk oxidn. that is most commonly postulated. These results demonstrate that the presence of surface steps can promote the development of a flat metal-oxide interface by kinetically suppressing subsurface oxide formation at the metal-oxide interface.

Using core-level spectroscopy and d. functional theory we show that a one-dimensional (1D) PtO2 oxide structure forms at the steps of the Pt(332) surface after O2 exposure. The 1D oxide is found to be stable in an oxygen pressure range, where bulk oxides are only metastable, and is therefore argued to be a precursor to the Pt oxidn. As an example of the consequences of such a precursor exclusively present at the steps, we investigate the reaction of CO with oxygen covered Pt(332). Albeit more strongly bound, the oxidic oxygen is found to react more easily with CO than oxygen chemisorbed on the Pt terraces.

Ackermann, M. D.; Pedersen, T. M.; Hendriksen, B. L. M.; Robach, O.; Bobaru, S. C.; Popa, I.; Quiros, C.; Kim, H.; Hammer, B.; Ferrer, S.; Frenken, J. W. M.

We present the first structure detn. by surface x-ray diffraction during the restructuring of a model catalyst under reaction conditions, i.e., at high pressure and high temp., and correlate the restructuring with a change in catalytic activity. We have analyzed the Pt(110) surface during CO oxidn. at pressures up to 0.5 bar and temps. up to 625 K. Depending on the O2/CO pressure ratio, we find three well-defined structures: namely, (i) the bulk-terminated Pt(110) surface, (ii) a thin, commensurate oxide, and (iii) a thin, incommensurate oxide. The commensurate oxide only appears under reaction conditions, i.e., when both O2 and CO are present and at sufficiently high temps. D. functional theory calcns. indicate that the commensurate oxide is stabilized by carbonate ions (CO32-). Both oxides have a substantially higher catalytic activity than the bulk-terminated Pt surface.

Probing surface oxide formations on SiO2-supported platinum nanocatalysts under CO oxidation
Oh, Sunyoung; Back, Seoin; Doh, Won Hui; Moon, Song Yi; Kim, Jeongjin; Jung, Yousung; Park, Jeong Young
RSC Advances
(
2017
),
7
(
71
),
45003-45009
CODEN:
RSCACL
; ISSN:
2046-2069
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Formations of an ultrathin oxide layer on noble metal catalysts affect the characteristics of fundamental mol. behaviors such as adsorption, diffusion, and desorption on their surfaces. That is directly correlated to enhancement of catalytic activity under operating conditions because the kinetics of catalytic reactions are also simultaneously influenced. Esp., a sub-monolayered surface oxide is known as having a key role for improving catalytic activity, but revealing its existence in catalysis is challenging due to their fast chem. conversion. Herein, we report the first evidence of surface oxide formations on platinum (Pt) nanocatalysts under CO oxidn. probed with a diffuse reflectance IR Fourier transform (DRIFT) technique. Spectroscopic information demonstrates that the abrupt blue shift of adsorbed CO mols. vibrational frequencies of C O stretching mode on the reduced Pt nanocatalyst surface is initiated prior to aggressive CO conversion to CO2 gas mols. Site-specific replacements of the adsorbed CO mol. with dissociative oxygen occur just before the ignition temp. that is supposed to be an important reaction step for CO oxidn. over a Pt nanocatalyst. D. functional theory (DFT) calcn. results support this phenomenon as a function of relative at. fractions between CO and O on a Pt model surface and consistently show a similar trend with exptl. evidence.

We demonstrate how shape selectivity and optimized surface compn. result in exceptional oxygen redn. activity of octahedral PtNi nanoparticles (NPs). The alloy octahedra were obtained by utilizing a facile, completely surfactant-free solvothermal synthesis. We show that the choice of precursor ligands controls the shape, while the reaction time tunes the surface Pt:Ni compn. The 9.5 nm sized PtNi octahedra reached a 10-fold surface area-specific (∼3.14 mA/cmPt2) as well as an unprecedented 10-fold Pt mass based (∼1.45 A/mgPt) activity gain over the state-of-art Pt electrocatalyst, approaching the theor. predicted limits.

Catalytic activity and durability improvements are still the main challenges in fuel cell commercialization. To enhance nanocatalyst performance and durability for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), we prep. 3.6 nm sized PtFe particles with a fully ordered intermetallic structure and entrap them in a porous carbon (
[email protected]
). This nanocatalyst toward ORR exhibits 8-10 times enhancement in specific and mass activities over the com. catalyst of Pt/C. Such a large enhancement is the highest, when compared with all other kinds of intermetallic catalysts reported in the literature. Accelerated durability testing has induced only a small change to the ordered structure and a minor loss of the activity after thousands of potential cycles under harsh electrochem. conditions. The high activity and durability are attributed to the fine-grained and ordered structure of the nanoparticle and the confining effect provided by the porous carbon. The nanoparticle,
[email protected]
, represents a new strategy for performance optimization and cost redn. and promoting practical applications of fuel cells.

Zhang, Zhicheng; Luo, Zhimin; Chen, Bo; Wei, Chao; Zhao, Jian; Chen, Junze; Zhang, Xiao; Lai, Zhuangchai; Fan, Zhanxi; Tan, Chaoliang; Zhao, Meiting; Lu, Qipeng; Li, Bing; Zong, Yun; Yan, Chengcheng; Wang, Guoxiong; Xu, Zhichuan J.; Zhang, Hua

Unique five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes are synthesized with nanothorns protruding from their edges, based on one-pot hydrothermal method. The time-dependent expt. showed that the pure Cu nanodecahedra were first formed. Then the galvanic replacement reaction between Cu nanodecahedra and Pt precursors in the soln., and the subsequent site-specific co-deposition of Pt and Cu atoms are responsible for the formation of highly anisotropic five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes. Impressively, the as-synthesized five-fold-twinned PtCu nanoframes exhibit enhanced electrocatalytic activity toward the oxygen redn. reaction and methanol oxidn. reaction as compared to the com. Pt/C catalyst and other reported PtCu nanostructures under alk. conditions. Bimetallic and multi-component catalysts typically exhibit compn.-dependent activity and selectivity, and when optimized often outperform single-component catalysts. Here we used ambient-pressure XPS (AP-XPS) and in situ and ex situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to elucidate the origin of compn. dependence obsd. in the catalytic activities of monodisperse CoPd bimetallic nanocatalysts for CO oxidn. We found that the catalysis process induced a reconstruction of the catalysts, leaving CoOx on the nanoparticle surface. The synergy between Pd and CoOx coexisting on the surface promotes the catalytic activity of the bimetallic catalysts. In2O3 has recently emerged as a promising catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO2. In this work, we present the promotional effect of Pd on this catalyst and investigate structure-performance relationships using in situ X-ray spectroscopy, ex situ characterization, and microkinetic modeling. Catalysts were synthesized with varying In:Pd ratios (1:0, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 0:1) and tested for methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 at 40 bar and 300 °C. In:Pd(2:1)/SiO2 shows the highest activity (5.1 μmol MeOH/gInPds) and selectivity toward methanol (61%). While all bimetallic catalysts had enhanced catalytic performance, characterization reveals methanol synthesis was maximized when the catalyst contained both In-Pd intermetallic compds. and an indium oxide phase. Exptl. results and d. functional theory suggest the active phase arises from a synergy between the indium oxide phase and a bimetallic In-Pd particle with a surface enrichment of indium. We show that the promotion obsd. in the In-Pd system is extendable to non precious metal contg. binary systems, in particular In-Ni, which displayed similar compn.-activity trends to the In-Pd system. Both palladium and nickel were found to form bimetallic catalysts with enhanced methanol activity and selectivity relative to that of indium oxide.

The selective oxidn. of ethanol with mol. O2 is increasingly becoming an important process to develop fine chems. because it can be obtained from renewable biomass feedstock while reducing the demand on fossil fuels. We have synthesized silica-supported Au-Cu alloy nanoparticles, and through an oxidative dealloying process, we have developed Au-CuOx hybrid catalysts for the selective oxidn. of ethanol into acetaldehyde. Using a combination of XRD, XPS, and HR-STEM expts., we have confirmed that the active catalyst is a Au core with a thin CuOx shell. Oxidn. of the AuCu/SiO2 alloy catalyst at 300 °C was found to produce the most active and stable catalyst for ethanol conversion (∼90%) with the highest selectivity (∼80-90%) at a reaction temp. of 200 °C for 50 h onstream. TEM and XRD results show that Au-CuOx/SiO2 catalysts calcined at 300 and 500 °C are also more resistant to sintering during pretreatment and catalytic conditions than pure gold supported on silica. Furthermore, the silica-supported Au-CuOx catalysts (calcined at 300 and 500 °C) were also found to be more active and selective in the dehydrogenation of ethanol to form acetaldehyde. It is likely that the increased interfacial contact between the Au and CuOx forms the most active site on the catalyst and is responsible for the enhanced catalytic properties when compared with pure Au/SiO2.

This work describes a mol.-level investigation of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) in Pt/TiO2 catalysts using sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy. This is the first time that SFG has been used to probe the highly selective oxide-metal interface during catalytic reaction, and the results demonstrate that charge transfer from TiO2 on a Pt/TiO2 catalyst controls the product distribution of furfuraldehyde hydrogenation by an acid-base mechanism. Pt nanoparticles supported on TiO2 and SiO2 are used as catalysts for furfuraldehyde hydrogenation. As synthesized, the Pt nanoparticles are encapsulated in a layer of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP). The presence of PVP prevents interaction of the Pt nanoparticles with their support, so identical turnover rates and reaction selectivity is obsd. regardless of the supporting oxide. However, removal of the PVP with UV light results in a 50-fold enhancement in the formation of furfuryl alc. by Pt supported on TiO2, while no change is obsd. for the kinetics of Pt supported on SiO2. SFG vibrational spectroscopy reveals that a furfuryl-oxy intermediate forms on TiO2 as a result of a charge transfer interaction. This furfuryl-oxy intermediate is a highly active and selective precursor to furfuryl alc., and spectral anal. shows that the Pt/TiO2 interface is required primarily for H spillover. D. functional calcns. predict that O-vacancies on the TiO2 surface activate the formation of the furfuryl-oxy intermediate via an electron transfer to furfuraldehyde, drawing a strong analogy between SMSI and acid-base catalysis.

To provide fundamental insight, the authors present a d. functional theory study of the structural change of Pt-3d transition metal (TM, including Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) alloys with (1 1 1) orientation under the reductive and oxidizing conditions as well as its effect on the CO oxidn. All of the Pt-3d-Pt(111) surfaces were found to have weaker oxygen binding energies than pure Pt(111) whereas all of the 3d-Pt-Pt(111) surfaces were found to have stronger oxygen binding energies than pure Pt(111). The total heat of reaction was calcd. for the segregation for 3d metal atoms from Pt-3d-Pt(111) to 3d-Pt-Pt(111) when exposed to a half monolayer of oxygen. All of the Pt-3d-Pt(111) subsurface structures were predicted to be thermodynamically unstable with adsorbed oxygen. In addn., the segregation of subsurface Ni and Co to the surfaces of Pt-Ni-Pt(111) and Pt-Co-Pt(111) was investigated exptl. using Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) and high-resoln. electron energy loss spectroscopy (HREELS). AES and HREELS confirmed the trend predicted by DFT modeling and showed that both the Pt-Ni-Pt(111) and Pt-Co-Pt(111) surface structures were unstable in the presence of adsorbed oxygen. The activation barrier of the segregation of subsurface Ni and Co atoms was detd. to be 15 ± 2 and 7 ± 1 kcal/mol, resp. These results are further discussed for their implication in the design and selection of cathode bimetallic electrocatalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in polymer electrode membrane (PEM) fuel cells.

The challenge of chem. in the 21st century is to achieve 100% selectivity of the desired product mol. in multipath reactions ("green chem.") and develop renewable energy based processes. Surface chem. and catalysis play key roles in this enterprise. Development of in situ surface techniques such as high-pressure scanning tunneling microscopy, sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy, time-resolved Fourier transform IR methods, and ambient pressure XPS enabled the rapid advancement of three fields: nanocatalysts, biointerfaces, and renewable energy conversion chem. In materials nanoscience, synthetic methods have been developed to produce monodisperse metal and oxide nanoparticles (NPs) in the 0.8-10 nm range with controlled shape, oxidn. states, and compn.; these NPs can be used as selective catalysts since chem. selectivity appears to be dependent on all of these exptl. parameters. New spectroscopic and microscopic techniques have been developed that operate under reaction conditions and reveal the dynamic change of mol. structure of catalysts and adsorbed mols. as the reactions proceed with changes in reaction intermediates, catalyst compn., and oxidn. states. SFG vibrational spectroscopy detects amino acids, peptides, and proteins adsorbed at hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces and monitors the change of surface structure and interactions with coadsorbed water. Exothermic reactions and photons generate hot electrons in metal NPs that may be utilized in chem. energy conversion. The photosplitting of water and carbon dioxide, an important research direction in renewable energy conversion, is discussed.

Concepts, instruments, and model systems that enabled the rapid evolution of surface science
Somorjai, Gabor A.; Park, Jeong Y.

A review. Over the past forty years, surface science has evolved to become both an at. scale and a mol. scale science. Gerhard Ertl's group has made major contributions in the field of mol. scale surface science, focusing on vacuum studies of adsorption chem. on single crystal surfaces. In this review, we outline 3 important aspects which have led to recent advances in surface chem.: the development of new concepts, in situ instruments for mol. scale surface studies at buried interfaces (solid-gas and solid-liq.), and new model nanoparticle surface systems, in addn. to single crystals. Combined mol. beam surface scattering and LEED- surface structure studies on metal single crystal surfaces revealed concepts, including adsorbate-induced surface restructuring and the unique activity of defects, at. steps, and kinks on metal surfaces. We have combined high pressure catalytic reaction studies with ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) surface characterization techniques using a UHV chamber equipped with a high pressure reaction cell. New instruments, such as high pressure sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) which permit mol.-level surface studies were developed. Tools that access broad ranges of pressures can be used for both the in situ characterization of solid-gas and solid-liq. buried interfaces and the study of catalytic reaction intermediates. The model systems for the study of mol. surface chem. have evolved from single crystals to nanoparticles in the 1-10 nm size range, which are currently the preferred media in catalytic reaction studies.

The structure of the Cu-Co (CuCo) surface alloy, formed by Co deposition on Cu(110), in dynamic equil. with CO, was studied. Using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), in vacuum at room temp. and at low Co coverage, clusters of a few Co atoms substituting Cu atoms form at the surface. At CO pressures in the Torr range, ≤2.5 CO mols. can bind on a single Co atom, in carbonyl-like configurations. Based on high-resoln. STM images, together with d. functional theory calcns., the most stable CuCo cluster structures formed with bound CO were detd. Such carbonyl-like formation manifests in shifts in the binding energy of the Co core-level peaks in x-ray photoelectron spectra, as well as shifts in the vibrational modes of adsorbed CO in IR reflection absorption spectra. The multiple CO adsorption on a Co site weakens the Co-CO bond and thus reduces the C-O bond scission probability. The results may explain the different product distribution, including higher selectivity toward alc. formation, when bimetallic CuCo catalysts are used compared to pure Co.
