The catalytic performance of nanoparticles is primarily detd. by the precise nature of the surface and near-surface at. configurations, which can be tailored by post-synthesis annealing effectively and straightforwardly. Understanding the complete dynamic response of surface structure and chem. to thermal treatments at the at. scale is imperative for the rational design of catalyst nanoparticles. Here, by tracking the same individual Pt3Co nanoparticles during in situ annealing in a scanning transmission electron microscope, we directly discern five distinct stages of surface elemental rearrangements in Pt3Co nanoparticles at the at. scale: initial random (alloy) elemental distribution; surface platinum-skin-layer formation; nucleation of structurally ordered domains; ordered framework development and, finally, initiation of amorphization. Furthermore, a comprehensive interplay among phase evolution, surface faceting and elemental inter-diffusion is revealed, and supported by atomistic simulations. This work may pave the way towards designing catalysts through post-synthesis annealing for optimized catalytic performance.

Surface segregation-the enrichment of one element at the surface, relative to the bulk-is ubiquitous to multi-component materials. Using the example of a Cu-Au solid soln., we demonstrate that compositional variations induced by surface segregation are accompanied by misfit strain and the formation of dislocations in the subsurface region via a surface diffusion and trapping process. The resulting chem. ordered surface regions acts as an effective barrier that inhibits subsequent dislocation annihilation at free surfaces. Using dynamic, at.-scale resoln. electron microscopy observations and theory modeling, we show that the dislocations are highly active, and we delineate the specific at.-scale mechanisms assocd. with their nucleation, glide, climb, and annihilation at elevated temps. These observations provide mechanistic detail of how dislocations nucleate and migrate at heterointerfaces in dissimilar-material systems.

Despite numerous studies, the origin of the enhanced catalytic performance of bimetallic nanoparticles (NPs) remains elusive because of the ever-changing surface structures, compositions, and oxidation states of NPs under reaction conditions. An effective strategy for obtaining critical clues for the phenomenon is real-time quantitative detection of hot electrons induced by a chemical reaction on the catalysts. STM shows that the defects with the strongest H2O adsorption are found above subsurface dislocations. To validate our model system, transmission Fourier-transform IR absorption spectroscopy (FTIR) studies at near-ambient pressures were carried out on monoclinic zirconia powder, showing comparable adsorption energies as TPD on the ultrathin film. Abstr.: Quant. measurement of the no. of active surface sites on two-dimensional (2D) catalysts is one of the most crucial points in heterogeneous catalysis because it is used to det. the turnover frequency (TOF), which refers to the catalytic activity of model catalysts. However, because of the difficulty in identifying the effective active surface area on 2D heterogeneous catalysts, there is still the assumption that each metal atom is an active site. To shed light on these issues and to bridge the activity gaps between 2D and three-dimensional (3D) heterogeneous catalysts, we present an exptl. approach that uses Pt nanoparticle (NP) arrays on a thin silicon wafer probed with CO pulse chemisorption, a widely used surface-sensitive technique, to det. the no. of active sites and the area of the effective active surface. A Pt thin film and Pt NP arrays with two different NP sizes (i.e., 2.1 and 4.5 nm) were prepd. as model systems for 2D catalysts. The effective active metal surface area detd. using CO pulse chemisorption for these 2D catalysts is 53-79% of the apparent metal surface area that was obtained by measuring the surface area based on SEM images. This discrepancy between the active and apparent surface area is attributed to the presence of hydrocarbon contamination and org. capping layers on the catalysts. The results indicate that estg. the active sites of 2D catalysts by apparent surface area is reasonably in agreement with the no. measured by chemisorption that is used to characterize 3D nanocatalysts. This exptl. technique on 2D catalysts can be expected to provide information for extg. the true TOF of product mols. on 2D catalysts in gas-phase catalytic reactions.

Bonakdarpour, A.; Wenzel, J.; Stevens, D. A.; Sheng, S.; Monchesky, T. L.; Lobel, R.; Atanasoski, R. T.; Schmoeckel, A. K.; Vernstrom, G. D.; Debe, M. K.; Dahn, J. R.

The dissoln. of Fe and Ni from Pt1-xMx (M = Fe, Ni; 0 < x<1) oxygen redn. electrocatalysts was studied under simulated operating conditions (low pH, 80°) of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. The alloys were prepd. combinatorially by sputtering Pt and M (M = Fe, Ni) onto thin films of nanostructured whisker-like supports, and mapped over the entire compn. range of the binary systems. For 0 < x< 1.0, the authors observe the formation of randomly ordered substitutional solid solns. of Pt1-xFex and Pt1-xNix alloys. Electron microprobe measurements show that transition metals are removed from all compns. during acid treatment, but that the percentage removed increases with x, acid strength, and temp. For small values of x (x < 0.6) no substantial changes in the lattice size are obsd. upon dissoln. of Fe or Ni suggesting that the dissolved transition metals originate from the surface. However, for electrocatalysts with x > 0.6, the lattice const. expands indicating that transition metals dissolve also from the bulk. XPS results show complete removal of surface Ni (Fe) after acid treatment at 80 °C for all compns. The results of the acid treatments compare well to the compn. changes that occur when a Pt1-xFex or Pt1-xNix combinatorial catalyst library is used in an operating PEM fuel cell.

Molecular adsorption on oxide surfaces: electronic structure and orientation of nitric oxide on nickel oxide(100)/nickel(100) and on nickel oxide(100) as determined from electron spectroscopies and ab initio cluster calculations
Kuhlenbeck, H.; Odoerfer, G.; Jaeger, R.; Illing, G.; Menges, M.; Mull, T.; Freund, H. J.; Poehlchen, M.; Staemmler, V.; et al.
Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics

The adsorption of NO was studied on a thin NiO(100) film of several layers thickness grown on top of a Ni(100) surface in comparison with data of an in vacuo cleaved NiO(100) single crystal. The layer exhibits a high defect d. XPS, angle-resolved RUPS near-edge x-ray-absorption fine structure (NEXAFS), and high-resoln. EELS studies indicate that this layer has similar occupied (ARUPS) and unoccupied (NEXAFS) states as a bulk NiO(100) sample. In spite of its limited thickness, the band structure of the film exhibits dispersions perpendicular to the surface compatible with bulk NiO(100). It is shown that the electronic structure of the O sublattice can be described in a band-structure picture, while for the Ni sublattice, electron localization effects lead to a breakdown of the band-structure picture. The NO on NiO desorbs at 220 K. This indicates weak chemisorption. The NO coverage is ∼0.2 relative to the no. of Ni surface atoms as detd. by XPS. HREELS reveals that there is only one species on the surface documented by th observation of only one bond-stretching frequency. NEXAFS data on the system and a comparison with previous data on the system NO/Ni(100) indicate that the mol. axis of adsorbed NO is tilted by an angle ∼45° relative to the surface normal. The N 1s XPS spectra of the weakly chemisorbed species show giant satellites similar to the previously obsd. cases for weak chemisorption on metal surfaces. This is the first observation of an intense satellite structure for an adsorbate on an insulator surface, which shows that there must be sufficient screening channels even on an insulating surface. A theor. assignment of the peaks is discussed. Spectroscopic properties of the NO species on the thin-film oxide surface (which is likely to contain a certain no. of defects) are compared with those of NO adsorbed on a basically defect-free bulk oxide surface by thermal-desorption (TDS) and XP spectra. TDS and XP spectra of the bulk system are basically identical as compared with the oxide film, indicating that the majority of species adsorbed on the film is not adsorbed on defects but rather on regular NiO sites. Results of ab initio oxide cluster calcns. are used to explain the bonding geometry of NO on regular NiO sites.

The surface chem. of the Ni-O system was studied by using both temp. changes and ion bombardment as techniques for elucidating the surface structure. The spectra of metallic Ni, NiO and Ni2O3 were characterized from samples prepd. directly in the spectrometer. The Ni2O3 species could be distinguished from an authentic Ni(OH)2 sample from both the x-ray photoelectron lines and the Auger transitions. The oxides of NiO and Ni2O3 could be prepd. by bombardment with low energy (400 eV) O2+ ions as well as by exposure of Ni to O at reduced pressure (∼100 torr). The Ni2O3 was present on most Ni-O surfaces except those prepd. by exposing Ni to air for many hours at high temp. (>600°), indicating that the stability of Ni2O3 decreased as the temp. increased. Exposure of both NiO and Ni2O3 to 400 eV Ar+ ion bombardment caused redn. to metallic Ni. This observation was noted for several other oxides and a prediction of whether or not redn. should be obsd. is presented by examg. the free energy of formation of the mol.

Using in situ at.-resoln. electron microscopy observations, we report observations of the oxide growth during the oxidn. of stepped Cu surfaces. Oxidn. occurs via direct growth of Cu2O on flat terraces with Cu adatoms detaching from steps and diffusing across the terraces. This process involves neither reconstructive oxygen adsorption nor oxygen subsurface incorporation and is rather different from the mechanism of solid-solid transformation of bulk oxidn. that is most commonly postulated. These results demonstrate that the presence of surface steps can promote the development of a flat metal-oxide interface by kinetically suppressing subsurface oxide formation at the metal-oxide interface.

Using core-level spectroscopy and d. functional theory we show that a one-dimensional (1D) PtO2 oxide structure forms at the steps of the Pt(332) surface after O2 exposure. The 1D oxide is found to be stable in an oxygen pressure range, where bulk oxides are only metastable, and is therefore argued to be a precursor to the Pt oxidn. As an example of the consequences of such a precursor exclusively present at the steps, we investigate the reaction of CO with oxygen covered Pt(332). Albeit more strongly bound, the oxidic oxygen is found to react more easily with CO than oxygen chemisorbed on the Pt terraces.

Structure and Reactivity of Surface Oxides on Pt(110) during Catalytic CO Oxidation
Ackermann, M. D.; Pedersen, T. M.; Hendriksen, B. L. M.; Robach, O.; Bobaru, S. C.; Popa, I.; Quiros, C.; Kim, H.; Hammer, B.; Ferrer, S.; Frenken, J. W. M.

We present the first structure detn. by surface x-ray diffraction during the restructuring of a model catalyst under reaction conditions, i.e., at high pressure and high temp., and correlate the restructuring with a change in catalytic activity. We have analyzed the Pt(110) surface during CO oxidn. at pressures up to 0.5 bar and temps. up to 625 K. Depending on the O2/CO pressure ratio, we find three well-defined structures: namely, (i) the bulk-terminated Pt(110) surface, (ii) a thin, commensurate oxide, and (iii) a thin, incommensurate oxide. The commensurate oxide only appears under reaction conditions, i.e., when both O2 and CO are present and at sufficiently high temps. D. functional theory calcns. indicate that the commensurate oxide is stabilized by carbonate ions (CO32-). Both oxides have a substantially higher catalytic activity than the bulk-terminated Pt surface.

Probing surface oxide formations on SiO2-supported platinum nanocatalysts under CO oxidation
Oh, Sunyoung; Back, Seoin; Doh, Won Hui; Moon, Song Yi; Kim, Jeongjin; Jung, Yousung; Park, Jeong Young

Formations of an ultrathin oxide layer on noble metal catalysts affect the characteristics of fundamental mol. behaviors such as adsorption, diffusion, and desorption on their surfaces. That is directly correlated to enhancement of catalytic activity under operating conditions because the kinetics of catalytic reactions are also simultaneously influenced. Esp., a sub-monolayered surface oxide is known as having a key role for improving catalytic activity, but revealing its existence in catalysis is challenging due to their fast chem. conversion. Herein, we report the first evidence of surface oxide formations on platinum (Pt) nanocatalysts under CO oxidn. probed with a diffuse reflectance IR Fourier transform (DRIFT) technique. Spectroscopic information demonstrates that the abrupt blue shift of adsorbed CO mols. vibrational frequencies of C O stretching mode on the reduced Pt nanocatalyst surface is initiated prior to aggressive CO conversion to CO2 gas mols. Site-specific replacements of the adsorbed CO mol. with dissociative oxygen occur just before the ignition temp. that is supposed to be an important reaction step for CO oxidn. over a Pt nanocatalyst. D. functional theory (DFT) calcn. results support this phenomenon as a function of relative at. fractions between CO and O on a Pt model surface and consistently show a similar trend with exptl. evidence.
